networking_ovn/tests/functional/test_rou.message: @Daniel: I could use some help from you on what this test is doing. It is still a bit confusing to me, but my changes to update_router could be missing something and it is important that we understand this test's expectations before going fwd.

In the setup (L35), we have two chassis:

        self.chassis1 = self.add_fake_chassis(
            'ovs-host1', physical_nets=['physnet1', 'physnet3'])
        self.chassis2 = self.add_fake_chassis(
            'ovs-host2', physical_nets=['physnet2', 'physnet3'])


Chassis1 is connected to both physnet1 and physnet3 while chassis2 is connected to physnet2 and physnet3.

The test is asserting that for every gw assigned to the router, the candidates are the right ones.

For example:

- In L216, ext1 is used and ext1 is assigned to physnet1 (L196) so this is why only chassis1 is expected as a candidate to schedule the gateway port (L215).

- Later in L225, ext2 (physnet3) is used so the expected candidates are chassis1 and chassis2 (L224)

- For ext3 no candidates are expected (L238) as there's no physnet associated to it (no bridge mappings), note the 'None' in L200.

Does it make sense?
OpenStack coding guidelines suggest to import modules and to avoid importing objects from modules: https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/latest/user/hacking.html#imports

Do you need it as a callable? I think you can simply do

 mock.patch.object( ..., return_value=[ovn_const.OVN_GATEWAY_INVALID_CHASSIS])
Indeed! I copied it from the other tests, but I think return value is cleaner here.
I think assertItemsEqual should work here too, no?
I didn't know about assertCountEqual :) Thanks for teaching me

Hm... that is a really good question! It seems that .assertItemsEqual is getting replaced by .assertCountEqual [1].
I will use that instead and save from adding the import as a bonus. Good deal. ;)
[1]: https://docs.python.org/3.2/library/unittest.html#unittest.TestCase.assertCountEqual

/COMMIT_MSG.message: kind of funny that this is the subject when most of the patch is actually the other bits.
do we want to specify that the commas should be every 8 hex characters?

tested in the lab:

controller-1:/home/wrsroot#  cat /proc/irq/default_smp_affinity
ffffffff,ffffffff
controller-1:/home/wrsroot# echo 1,1 > /proc/irq/default_smp_affinity
controller-1:/home/wrsroot# cat /proc/irq/default_smp_affinity
00000001,00000001

thanks for that, my observation about writing in smaller chunks was misinterpreted. incorrect.

Need to write it out like the following:
echo 3000,00000000,00000003 > default_smp_affinity

Or this,
echo 00003000,00000000,00000003 > default_smp_affinity 

Or this,
echo 00003000,0,00000003 > default_smp_affinity

based on  https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/lib/bitmap.c#n369 if you have a chunk representing less than 32 bits it will internally expand the chunk to 32 bits, which will not give the result you were looking for.
I found that I didn't have to put commas every 8, just some smaller chunk. I think I will adjust this statement to say: minimally comma delimited every 8 hex characters.

utilities/worker-utils/worker-utils/affi.message: nit: can you reformat this with split lines instead of a long line?
nit: isn't "nibble" usually four bits?  Here we're talking about 8-character chunks representing 32 bits of the resulting bitmask.

i found it doesn't seem to matter how often the commas are. so 4 or 8 will do; it might make it seem consistent if I remove the word nibble and change this to 8-character chunk by changing the '4' to an '8' in the sed pattern.

this seems to group things with commas every 4 hex characters.  I think we want every 8 hex characters.  (based on the comment at https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/lib/bitmap.c#n369 )
I will change the constant to 8 to be consistent. In practice, I found that this could be broken into seven maller chunks and it still worked the same.

I'm confused, why would we redirect stderr to /proc/irq/default_smp_affinity when we're trying to write something else to it already?  Wouldn't it make more sense to do "2>/dev/null" or something?

(Same below as well.)
only reason was to capture the resulting error string so could then print the actual reason that was being spewed out, eg, "echo: write error: Value too large for defined data type".

if I understand correctly the intent of this is to end up with errors being output on fd 1 (so they're saved), and the output of the "echo" command getting written to the file.  If so, this should have a comment explaining it.

mtce/src/hwmon/hwmonFsm.cpp.message: Do boards only allow access if the password is not empty?  Wondering about the case where the password isn't set and bmc access is performed.

The only BMC access that does not require a password is the root query which is really only used to see if a host supports Redfish. All IPMI or other Redfish requests, meaning 'functional accesses' require a password.

This update handles getting forcing a BMC password refresh by clearing bm_pw.

I don't want to declare BMC as accessible unless there is a password. 

When the BMC is deemed accessible then the FSM will start sensor monitoring and that won't work without a password.

just curious...are these actually *cores* or are we talking logical cpus? (ie hyperthread siblings if HT is enabled)

This looks to be logical cores not physical, so this is probably a bug for AIO hosts. We'll need to confirm what the original intent was. As this is existing code I think it is outside the scope of this issue.

original intent was to have minimum 2 physical cores. unfortunate this codebase uses 'cores', 'cpus', NUMA and CPUs loosely.

barbican/cmd/db_manage.py.message: Was there a reason this was changed?  And if it needs to be changed, should the help text be updated?
What's the intention of removing default value? Shouldn't the help message be changed as well?

thanks for your question, i will update the help message.

Why did i remove the default value? 

In the future, rolling upgrade is implemented. During rolling upgrade, if operators forget --expand or --contract option to upgrade database then the command will become "barbican-manage db upgrade". 

This is bad case because with the command then barbican will run expand phase and contract phase immediately => The process of rolling upgrade will be broken.

All get_*_id functions are not useful if UUIDs are not used. We assume heat templates use UUIDs (via get_resource) to get UUIDs of users/groups etc, but if UUIDs are not available For Eg: LDAP based users these functions are not useful. 
I recommend we make all these get_*_id functions support domain. This is discussed in the US: https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2005523.

The current implementation would support passing domain in two ways:
1) Pass the domain ID as a parameter to the function (This can be used anywhere in any heat resource)
2) Pass the domain along with group: group@domain (This is used by property constraints)

IIUC correctly we're trying to catch two different errors here:

* fail to assign the result of the split() to a 2-tuple because there's more than one '@'
* fail to look up the domain

They share the same error message (though print out different values for the group). It's better to be more explicit about which exceptions you're catching.

In this case I think we should just eliminate the first failure by doing something like:

  group, domain = group.split('@', 1)
I don't think replacing the EntityNotFound exception with an Invalid exception is the right thing to do here.

nodepool/tests/unit/test_launcher.py.message:
Note to reviewers: this section seems a bit racey. Specifically it's trying to assert that there are two ports that have leaked.

I think this check is unnecessary because of the stat check at the end of this check.

Well, the thing about only depending on stats reporting assert is that you are only asserting stats reporting. :)

If that were the only check, and it failed, you won't know if it was the stats reporting itself that failed, or something with cleaning up down ports. You'd then have to go back and add asserts to investigate and validate things you are assuming to be true before you get to the stats reporting part. I believe it's best to assert your assumptions as early as possible for when the test *does* fail.

Also, I don't think this is racey in it's original form. It may be NOW that you are lowering the cleanup interval early.
I agree with you on all counts, I was too hasty - an alternative way to model this test is to check if the timeout is semi-accurate by measuring the delay in port cleanup.
This assert should cover any possible race conditions. This stat will only be 2 if exactly 2 ports leaked.

I'd like for us to stop using the while-sleep waiting paradigm. We have something better in nodepool.nodeutils called iterate_timeout() that allows us to set a max wait time and throws an exception if that is exceeded. That prevents tests from running out of control until the max job timeout.
We *might* need to push this up a bit for any slow running VMs, but we can try it as-is for now.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I don't understand. Are you saying we catch the exception and we should not, or we do not catch the exception but we should?

As qga is not responsive, we did nothing inside VM.
Libvirt will report a VIR_ERR_AGENT_UNRESPONSIVE error.
We should catch this error.
Could you provide a little more context. Why is it necessary to special case this instance? Surely an error is an error? Also, why is NotImplementedError a suitable exception type to throw?

If we want to change password by qemu guest agent, we'll get:
1) success
2) qga not response to our command.
   Such as qga is not installed, crashed, halted, etc. Indeed qga did nothing to VMs, so NotImplementedError is a suitable case.
3) qga got our command but failed to exec it
  Such as lack of permission, selinux policy, change user 'root' in windows, etc. At this time, we may get other error from libvirt, indicated that we did something inside VM, but failed.
Then set vm_state to some suitable value is needed as we've already done.

nova/tests/functional/test_boot_from_vol.message:
The part that's silly is that a single instance would never (?) be using the same image more than once, right?

But we're proving it's theoretically possible for an instance to be using 255 BDMs.

And the important aspect of the caching is the server['min_count'] bit - that is, that we'll cache the image across multiple creates of the "same" instance.

What it *doesn't* mean is that we would cache an image across multiple *different* instance creations, which would seem like a nice thing to do. But perhaps that's done at the virt driver (if it supports imagecache) right?

The other thing that seems a bit light here is that we're not exercising the cache with more than one image. Would it be relatively easy to use two (or more) different images?

> Yeah I think I can bake that into the test pretty easily. I'll
 > probably do what I have here and then add an additional bdm which
 > uses some other image so ultimately with the cache we'd have 1 + 1
 > + 1 = 3 calls to GET /v2/images/{image_id}.

++

By the way, this came about in discussing Dan's aggregate-based image caching blueprint and rate limiting that API since while it might be silly to do so, technically his API will allow someone to send like 1000 images to cache. We got talking about other places in the API that aren't rate limited and this was one example and so I wrote a test to show that is the case and how it's easily fixed with a simple per-request cache.
Done - I decided to split it by 200 bdms for image1 and 55 bdms for image2.

> The part that's silly is that a single instance would never (?) be
 > using the same image more than once, right?

Yeah.

 > 
 > But we're proving it's theoretically possible for an instance to be
 > using 255 BDMs.

Yes.

 > 
 > And the important aspect of the caching is the server['min_count']
 > bit - that is, that we'll cache the image across multiple creates
 > of the "same" instance.

Yes. So excluding a case where a server has more than one bdm with the same image, you could definitely have a group of 10 servers with at least one bdm that are all using the same image, maybe multiple bdms using different images depending on the application (root bdm has the OS image, secondary bdms have some other non-OS filesystem images or something). So even in that case you'd have 10 or more GET calls to glance to get the image information.

 > 
 > What it *doesn't* mean is that we would cache an image across
 > multiple *different* instance creations, which would seem like a
 > nice thing to do. But perhaps that's done at the virt driver (if it
 > supports imagecache) right?

That's not something we could reasonably do in the API without some kind of TTL on the cache because the image could change status or property information between server create requests. Granted, for what the _validate_bdm code is doing, it's just an existence check really.

And yes if the compute driver supports the image cache and that's all setup then the compute service image cache manager will manage caching the image while it's in-use on that host (and related to the blueprint Dan is working on).

 > 
 > The other thing that seems a bit light here is that we're not
 > exercising the cache with more than one image. Would it be
 > relatively easy to use two (or more) different images?

Yeah I think I can bake that into the test pretty easily. I'll probably do what I have here and then add an additional bdm which uses some other image so ultimately with the cache we'd have 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 calls to GET /v2/images/{image_id}.

This instantiates networks, subnets, and VLAN configurations within MaaS which is a pre-requisite for ApplyNodeNetworking below using a series of API calls. None of this data directly arrives in the nodes interfaces files but it is necessary in a MaaS world as you cannot directly describe node networking in MaaS, it has to be done through a series of hooking network object X, Y, Z (which are artifacts now already existing in MaaS thanks to this call) to the node objects.

Ultimately this arrives in the config drive.  In a MaaS world, this facilitates a series of API calls against MaaS to "setup the node networking" in MaaS itself prior to provisioning so that when it is provisioned it receives the correct interfaces file.  As of MaaS 2.3, this is actually delivered via cloud-init.  This has no relation to the TOR switch. My impression of what how to deliver this with Ironic is that instead of trying to create a 1:1 situation where we bring in neutron that can be configured before provisioning and hooking up the node similar to what is done in MaaS that we simply bypass all of this and that these two steps help do is have *drydock* build the cloud-init declaration to directly feed to Ironic.

networking_vpp/taas_vpp.py.message: Why only if there is no port?

If there is no port for the tap_service it means we are in ERSPAN EXT Mode. There is no compute node associated with the tap service. Thus the tap service is put in active mode immediately. On the other hand, if there is a port, we have to wait for the compute node to answer via ectd before putting the tap_service in active mode.

The field port_id always exists as it's a field in the SQL database.
For ERSPAN EXT mode, it is set to an empty string : ''
This uses a set of conventions from your taas extensions that I think you need to document here in comments.

If the port_id is empty, we're in ERSPAN Ext mode.
If port_id is not empty and erspan_dst_ip is defined, we're in ERSPAN Internal mode. Otherwise we're in normal port tapping mode.

I could really use more comments here to tell me why this does what it does (and yes, I know this is largely unchanged) - but I don't know what tap_id_association is, I don't know why the VLAN would be out of the range, only above the range, and why that's special.

I'm also not sure (because you haven't written it down anywhere) what the different constructions are for external, internal and normal port tapping are - I can see some involve BDs and VLANs and some don't, but since you've never written down what you're planning, I'm now trying to reverse engineer your thinking.
OK, I'll add a description of the design for each mode.

keystoneauth1/session.py.message: It's not the responsibility of a patch submitter to correct unrelated pre-existing issues. Especially completely trivial ones.

IMO we can assign the initial value of connect_retries to None same as the other parameters for consistency.
I don't think we should as it's not a immutable type and consistent with L611.
Maybe we can have more opinions over this.

> Maybe we can have more opinions over this.

This is textbook bikeshedding.

I prefer (for simple consistency), "None" here with the rest of the default arguments, however, 0 is also 100% acceptable as long as the default behavior of None and 0 are the same as the current (prior to this patch) behavior.
If you want to worry about defaults, this is the one to worry about, because it means that if you set the Session's connect_retries there's no way to override it back to 0 for an individual request.
In that case, using None here and explicitly checking for 0 would make sense.

Zane had an interesting point about this in ps 3. If the Session attribute for retries is set, then a caller can't explicitly override a single request back to 0 by passing in:

  s.request('/v3/users', 'GET', connect_retries=0)

That call will always result in Session's connect_retries attribute being used if it is set to anything other than 0.

I added a test case that shows the broken behavior in a follow on patch:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678576/

Feel free to incorporate that test into this patch.

The change here is this should be changed to a None and session retries remain a zero. Coupled with changing line 738 to:

    if connect_retries is None:
        connect_retries = self._connect_retries

A test case to handle the 0 case ^ should be written.

As an aside, should we disallow negative retries?

keystoneauth1/tests/unit/test_session.py.message:
I would prefer this to be duplicated in each test rather than having logic that specifically handles "in-session" separate from "call_args".

Also, I recommend not starting with "test" or "_test" to disambiguate what is in-fact a test-case.

My recommendation is to structure the code like this:


    def _connect_retries_check(self, session, call_args=None):
	call_args = call_args or {}
        self.stub_url('GET', exc=requests.exceptions.Timeout())

        call_args['url'] = self.TEST_URL

        with mock.patch('time.sleep') as m:
            self.assertRaises(exceptions.ConnectTimeout,
                              session.get,
                              **call_args)

            self.assertEqual(retries, m.call_count)
            # 3 retries finishing with 2.0 means 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0
            m.assert_called_with(2.0)

        # we count retries so there will be one initial request + 3 retries
        self.assertThat(self.requests_mock.request_history,
                        matchers.HasLength(retries + 1))


    def test_session_connect_retries(self):
		session = client_session.Session(connect_retries=retries)
        self._connect_retries_check(session=session)


    def test_call_args_connect_retries_session_init(self):
		session = client_session.Session()
		call_args = {'connect_retries': 3}
        self._connect_retries_check(session=session, 
		                            call_args=call_args)



Note that session is now explicitly expected, so the test sets up the session as it requires (purview of the test case rather than the magic of the "test" that is called from within) and additional call args are optional, should be passed as a dict if needed.

releasenotes/notes/bug-1840235-ef2946d14.message: it's a feature, not a bug fix
Sure, if adding as a feature here does not impact it's backportability, then I'm fine.

Well, the backporting question is separate. From the library API standpoint it clearly adds a feature: new argument. A bug fix would be something that users will just get by updating the library (and only it).

> It may be a feature in keystoneauth

It is 100% a feature here, and this discussion is currently scoped to keystoneauth.

> I hope there would not be counter arguments from other folks that this is feature and can't be backported

I'm not overly optimistic here. But, as I mentioned, it does not depend on the text you write here.

This is new functionality. This is not fixing a bug, regardless of what is written in the release note. We use "RFE" Bugs in keystone (all keystone projects) for new features. The text here has no impact on my comments, I'll likewise add this same comment on the current patchset.

Putting on my stable core hat, this is not something we typically backport (new functionality), we almost always recommend folks moving forward to new releases, especially with keystoneauth. Keystoneauth's contract is explicitly designed to ensure as much compatibility across versions as possible.

Not sure if I would agree with that assertion. It may be a feature in keystoneauth, but it actually fixes a *bug* (which arises with the usage of the library) for it's consumers in stable branches.

That said, I hope there would not be counter arguments from other folks that this is feature and can't be backported, as we need to fix the issue in stable branches..

Well, we've been debating that in the review comments. Unless there is another way to fix the ConnectTimeout errors that affects scalability in stable branches, I would want this backported.

If it's just about the changing it in the releasenote, I can do that.
You're coming from a wrong perspective on it. It *is* a feature, hence it must be marked as such. And it is what affects the backportability, not the text here.

Yeah, it's a new feature in the library that's required to fix a bug. So I agree with the release note describing it as a feature.

I'm not sure where we stand on backporting stuff to libraries like this when bug fixes depend on it - I don't think the stable review guidelines were written with libraries in mind. I think SemVer would require a minor version bump, and that's possibly a good way to handle it. But all of this is a question for any future stable branch review :)

You can link the bug here in the release note like - 
[`bug xxx <https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/xxx>`_]

The bug report contains some useful information. We could link to it by convention [0] or by calling it out in the description below. For example:

  This would specifically help avoid a
  scalability `issue <https://launchpad.net/bugs/1840235>`_ ...
Yes this a feature but still we can tag the bug-ids in release notes for reference, since you have added the bug tag in your commit message.
It does not fix the bug alone and this change has been added as a feature in the releasenote, so, IMO not required.

tox.ini.message: I don't love the duplication. Is there a way to use {[testenv]deps} as a partial throughout?
This delta loses requirements.txt. Is that okay? What's venv used for anyway? Just running manual tools like reno etc? Anyway, probably better to leave it in for now.

> This delta loses requirements.txt. Is that okay?

requirements.txt might get applied by default, I'm not sure though.

 > What's venv used
 > for anyway? Just running manual tools like reno etc? Anyway,
 > probably better to leave it in for now.

Yes, and I use it for things like testing nova-manage command help, e.g. tox -e venv -- nova-manage cell_v2 heal_instance_mappings -?

mriedem is right, you don't need it because we're installing nova inside the virtualenv which brings in all the requirements listed inside requirements.txt (because that's what pbr uses). Note that we also don't have 'requirements.txt' listed in the top-level 'testenv'

> requirements.txt might get applied by default, I'm not sure though.

Unless by default for venv as a hardcoded special case, I'm 99% sure not. That's the point of having test-requirements.txt, so most of our envs can run *without* all the additional stuff required in a prod env.

 > Yes, and I use it for things like testing nova-manage command help,
 > e.g. tox -e venv -- nova-manage cell_v2 heal_instance_mappings -?

Ack, thanks for the confirmation.

> mriedem is right, you don't need it because we're installing nova
 > inside the virtualenv

Is that happening automatically because it's called venv? I can't see anything in this env's definition.

[Later] hum, no, the develop-inst thing seems to be happening regardless. Why? And thus, what's the point of having separate requirements and test-requirements??

[Later later] Oh, does this come from `usedevelop = True` in [testenv]? So... requiring requirements.txt is redundant everywhere (except where we're saying `usedevelop = False` explicitly).

[Later later later] Egads, with `usedevelop = False` tox actually pulls down a release zip of nova and installs *that*.

So here I thought all my venvs were smallish, only getting test-requirements, but they're getting the world. That makes me sad.

You can test this yourself.

  tox -e venv
  source .tox/venv/bin/activate
  pip freeze

It doesn't appear to work per env.

I played with trying to get functional-py36 to run with just test-requirements and got failures on a bunch of expected packages.

So clearly I was misunderstanding what test-requirements was supposed to be good for. I'm now thinking it's perhaps just for things we need in test that we *don't* need in the real world??

skipsdist is what you want to avoid doing that. Probably worth doing for pep8, tbh, but I don't know if it can be done on a per-venv basis. In any case, when that's set we wouldn't install the package so the only thing that would get installed is the deps you've listed

> So clearly I was misunderstanding what test-requirements was
 > supposed to be good for. I'm now thinking it's perhaps just for
 > things we need in test that we *don't* need in the real world??

The reason that I have pushed this patch is due to image registration. Specifically, When I was trying to register an image, the registration was failing (with a message that giving me the impression that the folder was not the proper one). Once, I manually created and used the 'v2/images' path instead of the 'images', the image had stored normally under the 'v2/images' path. I can collect logs about this behavior for sure. Maybe, my environment was not the updated , since I'm working using my fork for releng-xci and maybe I've lost some updates. I don't know. 
So, this patch is actually an improvement even if the filesystem path should be updated in the future for a specific scenario or something. Otherwise, the default value is remaining unaffected. 
That was the whole idea behind of this patch!
